facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 411 of 1959 filed by special leave from Allahabad High Court judgment dated 9th January 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 411 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 9th January 1959 of the Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 448/A of 1958.

facts.text: Three candidates Balwan Singh (appellant), Ram Dulari and Gaya Prasad contested election to UP Legislative Assembly from Akbarpur Rural Constituency No. 6 in 1957 general elections.

anchor.surface_text: Three candidates, Balwan Singh  hereinafter referred to as the appellant , Ram Dulari and Gaya Prasad, companytested the election to the U. P. Legislative Assembly from the Akbarpur Rural Assembly Constituency No. 6, at the last general elections held in 1957.

facts.text: Polling of votes took place on February 28, 1957, and result declared on March 2, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The polling of votes took place on February 28, 1957, and the result of the election was declared on March 2, 1957.

facts.text: Balwan Singh secured highest number of votes and was declared duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant secured the highest number of votes and was declared duly elected.

facts.text: Lakshmi Narain (first respondent) submitted election petition to Election Commission alleging corrupt practices by Balwan Singh including hiring bullock carts and tractors in 30 villages listed in Annexure D (Cl f para 9).

anchor.surface_text: A voter named Lakshmi Narain-who will hereinafter be referred to as the first respondent-submitted an application to the Election Commission of India to declare the election of the appellant Balwan Singh void on the ground inter alia that the appellant and or his election agent and or other persons with his companysent, had companymitted companyrupt practices... In Cl.  f  of para 9 of the petition... villages set out in annexure D, the appellant, his agents and workers with the companysent of the appellant, hired and procured bullock carts and tractors...

facts.text: Balwan Singh denied in written statement that he or his agents hired or procured vehicles for conveying women voters.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant by his written statement companytended that the averments made in Cl.  f  of para. 9 were untrue that neither he number his agents or workers had ever hired or procured bullock carts or trucks to companyvey women voters from the villages set out in Annexure D or any other village to the polling station.

facts.text: First respondent applied on July 15, 1957 for leave to amplify particulars including incorporating Ann. D-1 listing vehicles, owners, villages, hire paid.

anchor.surface_text: On July 15, 1957, the first respondent applied for leave to amplify the particulars set out in the various clauses of para. 9, including the particulars set out in Cl.  f  and prayed for leave to amplify the recitals in that clause by incorporating Ann. D-1 in the petition. In Ann. D-1, the first respondent set out the nature of the vehicles used, the names of the owners...

facts.text: Election Tribunal rejected application on July 29, 1957 and struck off Cl f para 9 and Annexure D.

anchor.surface_text: On July 29, 1957, the Election Tribunal rejected the application of the first respondent... and directed that certain paragraphs including Cl.  f  para. 9 and Annexure D be struck off.

facts.text: First respondent applied for review relying on Allahabad HC judgment dated September 9, 1957 in Mubarak Mazdoor v. K. K. Banerji.

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon a judgment of the Allahabad High Court delivered on September 9, 1957, Mubarak Mazdoor v. K. K. Banerji and another  1  in which, the practice to be followed in dealing with allegations of companyrupt practices...

facts.text: Election Tribunal on September 13, 1957 accepted review, set aside July 29 order.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal, by its order, dated September 13, 1957, accepted the plea of the first respondent for review of the order, and directed that the order dated July 29, 1957, beset aside.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Allahabad High Court under Art. 227 challenging Tribunal's review order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant applied under Art. 227 of the Constitution, to the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad, challenging the companyrectness and propriety of the order ,of the Election Tribunal reviewing its order dated July 29, 1957.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court on March 6, 1958 substantially confirmed Tribunal's order.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated March 6, 1958, the High Court substantially companyfirmed the order passed by the Tribunal.

facts.text: Election Tribunal on August 16, 1958 dismissed the election petition, holding corrupt practices not established.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated August 16, 1958, the Tribunal dismissed the petition holding that the first respondent failed to establish the companyrupt practices...

facts.text: Allahabad High Court in appeal under s.116A set aside Tribunal order, declared Balwan Singh's election void on January 9, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: In an appeal under s. 116A of the Respresentation of the People Act, against the order of the Election. Tribunal the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad set aside the order and declared the election of the appellant void.

facts.text: High Court found tractor hired for conveying voters to Naholi polling station based on evidence of A.P. Malik, Raghuraj Singh, Kalika Prasad, Hanuman Singh.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the High Court the testimony of A. P. Malik, the Presiding Officer at Naholi polling station, companyroborated by exh. 22, a petition submitted on the date of the polling by one Raghuraj Singh... established that voters were companyveyed in a trailer attached to a tractor... evidence of one Hanuman Singh established the companytract of hiring the tractor...

facts.text: Tractor belonging to Chandra Bahadur Pandey of village Chapargatha brought to Naholi polling station on polling day with red flag and posters of appellant's party.

anchor.surface_text: Raghuraj Singh, P.W. 38... had seen the tractor belonging to Chandra Bahadur Pandey of village Chapargatha, near the polling station that a red flag was hoisted and posters were pasted over the tractor with the symbol of a banyan tree...

facts.text: Kalika Prasad and female family members conveyed on tractor trailer to Naholi polling station by Radhey Shyam, agent of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Kalika Prasad was also examined and he stated that he and his wife and several other villagers had gone to the Naholi polling station to exercise their franchise on the trailer attached to the tractor...

facts.text: Hanuman Singh witnessed settlement of bargain for hiring tractor of Chandra Bahadur for conveying voters.

anchor.surface_text: Witness Hanuman Singh P.W. 56 deposed that he was present at the time of the settlement of the bargain of hiring the tractor belonging to Chandra Bahadur for companyveying voters.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal on February 23, 1960, upholding High Court declaration of election void.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. February, 23. The Judgment of Sinha, C. J. Imam, Wanchoo and Shah, JJ. was delivered by Shah, J.... The appeal, therefore, fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Petition lacked date and place of hiring tractor, names of parties to contract.

anchor.surface_text: Neither in the petition as originally filed number as amended, the date and place of hiring the tractor which was alleged to have been used for companyveying the voters, and the names of the persons between whom the companytract of hiring was settled, were set out.

facts.text: No material prejudice caused to appellant by lack of particulars as no objection pressed and evidence admitted without objection.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that... the petition was defective... the High Court, was right in holding that numbermaterial prejudice was occasioned thereby. In the written statement... Even after the petition was amended, numbersuch objection was raised...

The appellant applied under Art. 227 of the Constitution, to the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad, challenging the correctness and propriety of the order ,of the Election Tribunal reviewing its order dated July 29, 1957.

By its order dated March 6, 1958, the High Court substantially confirmed the order passed by the Tribunal. The High Court observed that the Tribunal had jurisdiction to review its earlier order, and that in the circumstances of the case it was unnecessary to decide whether the order dated September 13, 1957, was properly passed, because the order dated. July 29, 1957, was unjust and improper , and the matter having been brought before it in a proceeding under art. 227 of the Constitution,

concepts.interpretation: High Court used Art 227 to rectify improper order of Tribunal without deciding review power.

anchor.surface_text: But this appeal has been filed with special leave granted under Art. 136 of the Constitution. It is the settled practice of this Court to grant leave to appeal under Art. 136 only if exceptional and special circumstances exist, or that substantial and grave injustice has been done and the case presents features of sufficient gravity to warrant a review of the decision appealed against.

concepts.interpretation: Limits scope of SC review in SLP; no reappreciation of evidence unless exceptional circumstances; only points on which leave granted can be urged.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: r was carried a red flag of the party of the appellant, is established by the evidence of the two witnesses, Raghuraj Singh, P.W. 30 and Raghuraj Sing

anchor.surface_text: Merely because the appeal has been admitted by special leave, the entire case is not at large, and the appellant is not free to contest the findings of fact of the subordinate tribunals. Only those points on which special leave may initially be granted, can be urged at the final hearing and normally, special leave will not be granted by this Court under Art 136 1 of the Constitution on a plea of error committed by the Courts below in the appreciation of evidence.

concepts.interpretation: Normally no special leave on mere error in appreciation of evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Section 83 1 b of the Representation. of the People Act, as amended provides that an election petition shall set forth full particulars of any corrupt practice the petitioner alleges, including as full a statement as possible of the names of parties alleged to have committed such corrupt practice and the date and place of the commission of each such practice.

concepts.interpretation: Full particulars include names, date, place; but for s123(5), details of conveyance suffice over contract details.

anchor.surface_text: Section 123 sets out what shall be deemed to be corrupt practices for the purposes of the Act, and by Cl. 5 thereof, as it stood at the material date, it was in so far as it is relevant, provided The hiring or procuring, whether on payment or otherwise, of any vehicle or vessel by a candidate or his agent or by any other person for the conveyance of any elector  other than the candidate himself, the members of his family or his agent  to or from any polling station

concepts.interpretation: Corrupt practice is hiring/procuring vehicle for conveyance; conveyance details in petition suffice, contract particulars not essential if within special knowledge of other party.

anchor.surface_text: There was before the Tribunal the evidence of Mr. A. P. Malik... We may, however, observe that even on a review of the evidence, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in its companyclusion.

arguments.claim: s123(5) requires particulars of hiring contract (date, place, parties) as hiring essential element; but no dismissal for s83 non-compliance, s90(3) excludes; no application for particulars made, trial without grievance.

holdings.text: An election petition is not liable to be dismissed in limine merely because full particulars of a corrupt practice alleged in the petition are not set out.

anchor.surface_text: The practice to be followed in cases where insufficient particulars of a corrupt practice are set forth in an election petition is this. An election petition is not liable to be -dismissed in limine merely because full particulars of a corrupt practice alleged in the petition, are not set out.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.90(5) allows amendment/amplification; s.90(1) applies CPC procedure; s.90(3) mandates dismissal only for ss.81,82,117 not s.83; objection must be decided, opportunity to amend given before striking out.

holdings.text: Particulars of the use of a vehicle for conveying voters suffice to comply with s.83(1)(b) for corrupt practice under s.123(5); details of hiring contract (date, place, parties) not essential as within special knowledge of other party.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of s.123(5) focuses on hiring for conveyance, not contract itself; conveyance inseparable from hiring; purposive reading avoids requiring petitioner to plead other party's special knowledge facts.

holdings.text: If parties proceed to trial despite absence of full particulars and lead evidence without objection, petition cannot thereafter be dismissed for want of particulars as defect is procedural not jurisdictional.
holdings.reasoning_summary: CPC procedure under s.90(1); tribunal strikes only after order for particulars and non-compliance; trial cures procedural defect unless prejudice.

holdings.text: No material prejudice occasioned by absence of full particulars where no objection raised in written statement or pressed before trial, and evidence admitted without objection.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Failure to raise/press objection weighs against prejudice claim; no embarrassment in defense shown; evidence on issue admitted freely.

holdings.text: Election Tribunal's order rejecting application to amplify particulars erroneous.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows practice for handling insufficient particulars; unjust per HC under Art.227.

holdings.text: Special leave under Art.136 granted only for exceptional circumstances or grave injustice; does not open entire case or permit reappreciation of evidence or contesting findings of fact.

anchor.surface_text: It is the settled practice of this Court to grant leave to appeal under Art. 136 only if exceptional and special circumstances exist, or that substantial and grave injustice has been done and the case presents features of sufficient gravity to warrant a review of the decision appealed against.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Settled practice limits SLP scope; only points on which leave granted arguable; no leave normally on mere evidence appreciation error.

holdings.text: Even on review of evidence, High Court right that corrupt practice under s.123(5) established by testimony of Malik, Raghuraj Singh, Kalika Prasad, Hanuman Singh re tractor at Naholi.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Unimpeachable evidence of tractor with party symbols conveying voters; hiring bargain witnessed; Tribunal fanciful rejection.

holdings.text: Tribunal not liable to dismiss petition for non-compliance with s.83 as s.90(3) specifies only ss.81,82,117; no automatic dismissal for lack of particulars.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.90(3) excludes s.83; CPC applies for particulars order.

precedents.citation: Mubarak Mazdoor v. K. K. Banerji and another 1

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon a judgment of the Allahabad High Court delivered on September 9, 1957, Mubarak Mazdoor v. K. K. Banerji and another 1 in which, the practice to be followed in dealing with allegations of companyrupt practices, made in an election petition, on the ground of vagueness, was enunciated the first respondent applied for review of that order.

precedents.case_name: Mubarak Mazdoor v. K. K. Banerji
precedents.cited_proposition: practice to be followed in dealing with allegations of corrupt practices made in an election petition on the ground of vagueness

precedents.citation: Madan Lal v. Syed Zargham Haider and others 1

anchor.surface_text: In so opining, the High Court relied upon an earlier decision of that Court, Madan Lal v. Syed Zargham Haider and others 1 . In that case, Bhargava, J., delivering the judgment of the Court, observed under s. 123 5  of the Representation of the People Act, a companyrupt practice companysists in the act of hiring or procuring certain types of vehicles by a candidate or his agent or by any other person for the companyveyance of any elector to or from any polling station.

precedents.case_name: Madan Lal v. Syed Zargham Haider
precedents.cited_proposition: corrupt practice under s.123(5) consists in the act of hiring or procuring vehicles, not merely conveying voters; requires full particulars including names, date and place of commission
precedents.cited_holding: a corrupt practice consists in the act of hiring or procuring certain types of vehicles by a candidate or his agent or by any other person for the conveyance of any elector to or from any polling station. A corrupt practice is, therefore, committed not by conveying the voter but by the act of hiring or procuring the conveyance.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal, therefore, fails and is dismissed with costs.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal fails and is dismissed with costs; High Court order declaring appellant's election void upheld
